#Text=Chapter XIX
#Text=The Viscount and the Persian

#Text=Raoul now remembered that his brother had once shown him that mysterious person , of whom nothing was known except that he was a Persian and that he lived in a little old-fashioned flat in the Rue de Rivoli .
#Text=The man with the ebony skin , the eyes of jade and the astrakhan cap bent over Raoul .
#Text=" I hope , M. de Chagny , " he said , " that you have not betrayed Erik 's secret ? "
#Text=" And why should I hesitate to betray that monster , sir ? " Raoul rejoined haughtily , trying to shake off the intruder .
#Text=" Is he your friend , by any chance ? "
#Text=" I hope that you said nothing about Erik , sir , because Erik 's secret is also Christine Daae 's and to talk about one is to talk about the other ! "
#Text=" Oh , sir , " said Raoul , becoming more and more impatient , " you seem to know about many things that interest me ; and yet I have no time to listen to you ! "
#Text=" Once more , M. de Chagny , where are you going so fast ? "
#Text=" Can not you guess ?

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= Then , sir , stay here , for Christine Daae is here ! "

column1: #Text=" With Erik ? "
#Text=" With Erik . "
#Text=" How do you know ? "
#Text=" I was at the performance and no one in the world but Erik could contrive an abduction like that ! ...
#Text=The Persian did not reply , but heaved a fresh sigh .
#Text=" Sir , " said Raoul , " I do not know what your intentions are , but can you do anything to help me ?

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= I think so , M. de Chagny , and that is why I spoke to you . "

column1: #Text=" What can you do ? "
#Text=" Try to take you to her ... and to him . "
#Text=" If you can do me that service , sir , my life is yours ! ...

#Text=One word more : the commissary of police tells me that Christine Daae has been carried off by my brother , Count Philippe .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Oh , M. de Chagny , I do n't believe a word of it . "

column1: #Text=" It 's not possible , is it ? "
#Text=" I do n't know if it is possible or not ; but there are ways and ways of carrying people off ; and M. le Comte Philippe has never , as far as I know , had anything to do with witchcraft . "
#Text=" Your arguments are convincing , sir , and I am a fool ! ...

#Text=... How should I not believe you , when you are the only one to believe me ... when you are the only one not to smile when Erik 's name is mentioned ?

_	_	_	_

#Text=And the young man impetuously seized the Persian 's hands .

#Text= Silence ! " said the Persian , stopping and listening to the distant sounds of the theater .

column1: #Text=" We must not mention that name here .

#Text=Let us say ' he ' and ' him ; ' then there will be less danger of attracting his attention .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Do you think he is near us ? "

column1: #Text=" It is quite possible , Sir , if he is not , at this moment , with his victim , IN THE HOUSE ON THE LAKE . "
#Text=" Ah , so you know that house too ? "
#Text=" If he is not there , he may be here , in this wall , in this floor , in this ceiling ! ...

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=And the Persian , asking Raoul to deaden the sound of his footsteps , led him down passages which Raoul had never seen before , even at the time when Christine used to take him for walks through that labyrinth .

#Text= If only Darius has come ! " said the Persian .

column1: #Text=" Who is Darius ? "
#Text=" Darius ?
#Text=" I said that Christine Daae 's abductor was the Angel of Music , ALIAS the Opera ghost , and that the real name was ... "
#Text=" Hush !

column3:
_	_	_	_

54-3	3658-3659	!	_	_	_	_

#Text=... And did he believe you ?

column1: #Text=" He attached no importance to what you said ? "
#Text=" No. "
#Text=" He took you for a bit of a madman ? "
#Text=" Yes . "
#Text=" So much the better ! " sighed the Persian .
#Text=And they continued their road .
#Text=After going up and down several staircases which Raoul had never seen before , the two men found themselves in front of a door which the Persian opened with a master-key .
#Text=The Persian and Raoul were both , of course , in dress-clothes ; but , whereas Raoul had a tall hat , the Persian wore the astrakhan cap which I have already mentioned .

#Text=It was an infringement of the rule which insists upon the tall hat behind the scenes ; but in France foreigners are allowed every license : the Englishman his traveling-cap , the Persian his cap of astrakhan .
#Text=" Sir , " said the Persian , " your tall hat will be in your way : you would do well to leave it in the dressing-room . "
#Text=" What dressing-room ? " asked Raoul .
#Text=" Christine Daae 's . "
#Text=And the Persian , letting Raoul through the door which he had just opened , showed him the actress ' room opposite .
#Text=They were at the end of the passage the whole length of which Raoul had been accustomed to traverse before knocking at Christine 's door .
#Text=" How well you know the Opera , sir ! "
#Text=" Not so well as ' he ' does ! " said the Persian modestly .
#Text=And he pushed the young man into Christine 's dressing-room , which was as Raoul had left it a few minutes earlier .
#Text=Closing the door , the Persian went to a very thin partition that separated the dressing-room from a big lumber-room next to it .
#Text=He listened and then coughed loudly .
